name: Capstone: Secure Your Journal API
description: You've learned about IAM, encryption, network security, monitoring, and incident response. Now it's time to put it all together. In this capstone, you'll take your Journal API from previous phases and harden it with real security controls. By the end, you'll have a production-ready, genuinely secure application—and a great portfolio piece that shows employers you understand cloud security.
short_description: Harden your Journal API with IAM, secrets management, network controls, monitoring, and incident response—make it production-ready.

learning_steps.description:
You're going to secure your Journal API across five security domains—the same domains real security teams audit:

1. Identity & Access Management
2. Data Protection & Secrets
3. Network Security
4. Security Monitoring
5. Incident Response

Don't rush this. Work through each section carefully and test as you go. When you're done, you'll have a genuinely hardened cloud application.

First up—make sure the right people (and services) have the right access, and nobody else does:

- Create a dedicated service account for your Journal API (stop using your personal credentials!)
- Set up role-based access control (RBAC) with least-privilege permissions
- Enable MFA for all admin access to your cloud account
- Make sure your API authentication is solid (JWT tokens, API keys—whatever you set up in Phase 3)
- Search your codebase for any hardcoded credentials and remove them
learning_steps.title: IAM Security

learning_steps.description:
Before moving on, make sure you can check off each of these:

- [ ] Dedicated service account created for the API
- [ ] IAM roles defined with minimum required permissions
- [ ] API key or credential rotation configured
- [ ] Conditional access or IP restrictions in place
- [ ] Audit logging enabled for all IAM changes

Your users' journal entries are their private thoughts—treat them that way:

- Enable encryption at rest for your PostgreSQL database
- Configure TLS/HTTPS for all API endpoints (no plaintext traffic!)
- Move your database password, LLM API key, and any other secrets into a secrets manager
- Set up encrypted backups for your database
- Document what data your app stores and how sensitive each type is
learning_steps.title: Data Protection

learning_steps.description:
Check these off:

- [ ] Database encryption at rest is enabled
- [ ] All API traffic uses HTTPS/TLS
- [ ] Secrets moved from .env files to a cloud secrets manager
- [ ] Database backups are encrypted
- [ ] Data classification documented (what's stored, how sensitive is it)

Your database should not be reachable from the internet. Let's make sure of that:

- Set up a VPC with separate public and private subnets
- Put your API behind a load balancer in the public subnet
- Move your database to a private subnet with no internet access
- Configure security groups so only your API can talk to the database
- Set up a WAF (Web Application Firewall) if your provider supports it
learning_steps.title: Network Security

learning_steps.description:
Check these off:

- [ ] VPC architecture designed with public/private subnets
- [ ] Security groups configured (API, database, bastion if needed)
- [ ] Network ACLs set up for subnet-level protection
- [ ] Load balancer configured with SSL termination
- [ ] Network architecture diagram documented

Now that your app is secured, you need to know if anyone tries to mess with it:

- Enable audit logging for all cloud services (CloudTrail, Activity Log, etc.)
- Set up a central place for all your logs
- Build a simple security dashboard showing key metrics
- Create alerts for the events that matter most (failed logins, config changes, unusual traffic)
- Define what "normal" looks like so you can spot anomalies
learning_steps.title: Security Monitoring

learning_steps.description:
Check these off:

- [ ] Cloud audit logging enabled (CloudWatch/Azure Monitor/Cloud Logging)
- [ ] Log retention policies configured
- [ ] Security event dashboard created
- [ ] Alerts set up for critical events (failed auth, config changes)
- [ ] Security metrics and thresholds defined

The best time to plan for a security incident is before it happens. Set up your response capabilities:

- Enable your cloud provider's threat detection service (GuardDuty, Sentinel, etc.)
- Write a runbook for the most likely incident: "What do we do if credentials are leaked?"
- Set up at least one automated response (e.g., block an IP after repeated failed logins)
- Document your escalation process—who gets notified at each severity level
- Create a post-incident review template
learning_steps.title: Incident Response

learning_steps.description:
Check these off:

- [ ] Threat detection service enabled (GuardDuty/Sentinel/SCC)
- [ ] Runbook written for credential compromise scenario
- [ ] At least one automated response configured
- [ ] Incident severity matrix documented
- [ ] Communication/escalation templates created

Step back and verify your implementation meets these benchmarks:

- Zero secrets in your code or environment variables—everything is in a secrets manager
- Your database is not accessible from the public internet
- All traffic is encrypted (HTTPS for the API, TLS for database connections)
- Monitoring is active and you have at least one working alert
- You have at least one automated response configured
- Your security posture is documented
- You're staying within your cloud budget (set up billing alerts if you haven't)

Document and share your work—this is great portfolio material:

1. Security architecture diagram (show your VPC, subnets, security groups)
2. IAM roles and policies documentation
3. Network architecture with security controls labeled
4. Screenshots of your monitoring dashboard and alerts
5. Your incident response runbook
6. A brief security assessment: what you secured, what risks remain, what you'd do next

Push everything to your GitHub repo. Consider sharing it on LinkedIn or the L2C Discord—you've earned it!
